6.1 eGain warrants and represents to Customer that (i) the Software will perform substantially in accordance with the documentation, if any, provided by eGain to Customer, and (ii) the Hosting Services will be performed in a professional and workmanlike manner and in accordance with Section 2. In the event of Downtime (as defined in this Section 6.1 below), as Customer's sole and exclusive remedy and eGain's sole and exclusive liability, the monthly fee payable for the Hosting Services shall be reduced as follows:

a) For the first sixty (60) minutes of Downtime during Normal Business       Hours or the first four (4) hours of Downtime outside of Normal Business       Hours ("Initial Downtime"), eGain will credit Customer's account for one       (1) day of service.

b) For each eight (8) hour period of Downtime per day in addition to the       Initial Downtime, eGain will credit Customer's account for one (1)       additional day of service.

For the purposes of this Agreement, "Downtime" shall mean any interruption in the availability of Hosting Services to Customer (excluding scheduled interruptions of which Customer is notified 48 hours in advanced), only if such interruption is due either to: 1) an error in the Software, or 2) failure of the eGain System (but not including problems associated with Internet connectivity). Downtime begins upon Customer notification to eGain of the interruption, either
perturbation.changed_text: 6.1 eGain warrants and represents to Customer that (ii) the Hosting Services will be performed in a workmanlike manner and in accordance with Section 2. In the event of Downtime (as defined in this Section 6.1 below), the monthly fee payable for the Hosting Services may be reduced. The determination of any reduction will be at eGain's sole discretion.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause provides a specific remedy (service credit) for downtime, essentially a service level agreement (SLA). Removing the guarantee of substantial performance and the detailed Downtime credit system, and replacing it with a vague 'may be reduced' gives eGain complete control, potentially violating implied warranties or reasonable expectations under California law regarding service reliability and remedies.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Implied Warranty/Reasonable Expectation (California Commercial Code)

perturbation.original_text: Payment received by eGain after the due date shall be subject to a late fee equal to one and one-half percent (1.5%) per month, or, if less, the maximum amount allowed by applicable law.
perturbation.changed_text: Payment received by eGain after the due date shall be subject to a late fee.
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'equal to one and one-half percent (1.5%) per month, or, if less, the maximum amount allowed by applicable law,' the contract now has no cap on late fees. California law limits late fees to a reasonable amount, and failing to specify this cap opens eGain up to charging potentially usurious or unconscionable late fees. This conflicts with California's consumer protection laws against excessive charges.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Civil Code Section 1671 (Liquidated Damages) and usury laws

of such termination upon the other party's material breach of any material term (subject to the other party's right to cure within thirty (30) days after receipt of such notice), the other party's insolvency, or the institution of any bankruptcy or similar proceedings by or against the other party.
perturbation.changed_text: In addition, eGain may terminate this Agreement by giving to the other party written notice of such termination upon the Customer's material breach of any term, the other party's insolvency, or the institution of any bankruptcy or similar proceedings by or against the other party.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the Customer's right to terminate the agreement for eGain's breach creates an imbalance in the contract. Under California law, both parties generally have the right to terminate a contract for material breach by the other party. Eliminating this right for the Customer makes the contract potentially unconscionable and unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing (California contract law)
